get out.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to leave a room or building
get out.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: You ought to get out into the fresh air.
Mary screamed at me to get out.
get out.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Some of the animals had got out.
He was determined to get out of prison.
get out.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to help someone leave a place or escape from a place
get out.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: It’s important to get these people out as soon as possible.
We knew it was going to be difficult to get him out of the country.
get out.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to take something from the place where it is kept
get out.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: She got out her violin and started to play.
get out.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if information gets out, a lot of people then know it although it is meant to be secret
get out.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: We have to make absolutely certain that none of this gets out.
It’s bound to get out that he’s retiring soon.
get out.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to produce a book or other product that can be sold to people
get out.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: We’re hoping to get the new catalogue out next week.
get out.translation[0].definitions[6].de: to succeed in saying something, especially when this is very difficult
get out.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: I wanted to tell him I loved him, but couldn’t get the words out.
get out.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to stop investing in or making a particular product or performing a particular activity, usually because it is no longer making a profit
get out.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Investors can get out early if trouble arises.
Most banks are now getting out of development finance.
get out.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to avoid meeting the terms of a contract, agreement etc
get out.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The company hopes the move will let it get out of costly gas supply contracts.
get out.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to succeed in producing something and making it available
get out.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: We must get those letters out on time.
IBM wanted to get out a system that the novice could use.
